title: 108_hr1334
content:
The "Brownfield Redevelopment Assistance Act of 2003" aims to provide targeted assistance for projects that promote the redevelopment of brownfield sites and eco-industrial development. It also seeks to restore employment and tax bases in distressed communities that have not fully participated in the economic growth of the United States. Section 3 of the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to include definitions for "brownfield site" and "eco-industrial development." The amendment aims to provide funding for site characterization, assessment, and remediation of brownfield sites under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. The term 'eco-industrial development' refers to businesses cooperating to efficiently share resources for economic gains, improved environmental quality, and equitable enhancement of human resources. Additionally, 'unused land' is defined as land that is not contributing to the community's quality of life or economic well-being. SEC. 4. COORDINATION.

Amends Section 103 of the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 to include coordination of brownfield site redevelopment activities with other entities.

SEC. 5. GRANTS FOR BROWNFIELD SITE REDEVELOPMENT. SEC. 5. Grants for Brownfield Site Redevelopment under Title II of the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 are amended to include new sections for grants specifically for brownfield site redevelopment. The Secretary may make grants for projects to alleviate conditions associated with brownfield sites, including development of public facilities, services, business, planning, technical assistance, training, and purchase of environmental insurance. Grants can only be provided if the project meets specific criteria. The Secretary can provide grants for projects in areas with special needs like high unemployment, blight, dislocations from restructuring, and outmigration leading to population loss. The Secretary can provide grants for projects in areas with special needs like high unemployment, blight, dislocations from restructuring, and outmigration leading to population loss. The grants may be used for projects related to firms, investment, shrinking tax base, fiscal pressure, restricted access to markets, constrained local development potential, and the closure or realignment of military or federal facilities. Approval of a comprehensive economic development strategy is required for projects, except for planning or technical assistance. Assistance under this section may include revitalizing affected areas by diversifying the economy, carrying out redevelopment projects on brownfield sites, and conserving land through reusing existing facilities and reclaiming unused land. The grant funds can be used for revitalizing areas by diversifying the economy, redeveloping brownfield sites, and conserving land through various means such as reclaiming unused land and promoting eco-industrial development. Recipients can directly expend the funds or redistribute them to public and private entities for economic development planning. The grant funds can be used for revitalizing areas by diversifying the economy, redeveloping brownfield sites, and conserving land through various means such as reclaiming unused land and promoting eco-industrial development. Recipients can directly expend the funds or redistribute them to public and private entities for economic development planning. The entities can receive assistance in the form of a grant, loan, loan guarantee, or payment to reduce interest on a loan guarantee, with a limitation that grants cannot be provided to private for-profit entities. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents in the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Title VII of the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to include authorization of appropriations for brownfield site redevelopment. SEC. 704 authorizes $60,000,000 for brownfield site redevelopment annually from 2004 to 2008, with a federal share of up to 75 percent.
